issues.title: Missing Administrative Regulation for Certificated Personnel
issues.description: The Board Policy establishes general principles for certificated personnel management but lacks the corresponding Administrative Regulation that should detail the specific procedures for implementation. This creates a significant gap in operational guidance for staff responsible for managing certificated personnel, including hiring procedures, evaluation processes, professional development requirements, and other day-to-day administrative functions.

legal_citations.text: The governing board of each school district shall establish policies for the evaluation and assessment of the performance of certificated employees and shall ensure that competent personnel evaluate and assess certificated employee performance.

issues.required_language: An Administrative Regulation should be developed to include: (1) Specific procedures for certificated personnel evaluation consistent with Education Code requirements and collective bargaining agreements; (2) Professional development and continuing education requirements; (3) Procedures for defining and communicating job duties and responsibilities; (4) Performance improvement processes; (5) Documentation and record-keeping requirements; (6) Timeline and notification procedures for evaluations.

issues.title: Lack of Specific Evaluation Requirements and Procedures
issues.description: While the policy mentions that certificated staff "shall undergo regular performance evaluations in accordance with law and negotiated agreements," it fails to specify the required evaluation procedures, timelines, criteria, or documentation requirements mandated by California Education Code. This omission could lead to non-compliance with state evaluation requirements.

legal_citations.text: The performance of each certificated employee shall be evaluated and assessed as it reasonably relates to: (a) The progress of pupils toward the standards established pursuant to Section 60605, and other measures of pupil progress that may be established by the governing board, (b) The instructional techniques and strategies used by the employee, (c) The employee's adherence to curricular objectives, (d) The establishment and maintenance of a suitable learning environment.

issues.required_language: Evaluation procedures must address the four statutory criteria: student progress toward established standards, instructional techniques and strategies, adherence to curricular objectives, and establishment of suitable learning environment. Specific timelines, evaluation instruments, and documentation requirements should be established consistent with Education Code requirements.

issues.title: Missing Professional Development and Continuing Education Requirements
issues.description: The policy encourages professional development but does not address mandatory continuing education requirements for maintaining teaching credentials or other certificated positions. California law requires specific professional development for credential renewal and maintenance.

legal_citations.text: Each person employed in a position requiring certification qualifications shall complete the continuing education or professional growth requirements prescribed by the Commission on Teacher Credentialing as a condition of employment.

issues.required_language: Certificated personnel must complete continuing education and professional growth requirements as prescribed by the Commission on Teacher Credentialing. The district shall provide information and support for meeting these requirements and shall monitor compliance as a condition of continued employment.

issues.title: Outdated Policy Review Date
issues.description: The policy was last reviewed in 2009, which is over 14 years ago. Given the significant changes in education law, credentialing requirements, and evaluation standards since then, this policy should be reviewed and updated to ensure current compliance with state requirements.

legal_citations.text: The governing board of a school district may initiate and carry on any program or activity or may otherwise act in any manner which is not in conflict with or inconsistent with or preempted by any law and which is not in conflict with the purposes for which school districts are established.

issues.required_language: Regular policy review and updates should be conducted to ensure continued compliance with current state law and regulations.
